captions.text:
Hey, Vsauce, Michael here, and when the pyramids
of Giza were built, the tallest was 147 meters

tall, making them the tallest things humans
had ever built. And they remained that way

for nearly 4,000 years. It wasn't even until
the 1300's that we finally got around to making

something taller, a cathedral in England.
So, does that mean that the Great Pyramids

of Giza are the "Best tallest structures Of
All Time?"
Well, to find out more, all aboard the BOAT.

So, what is a building? Well, technically,
a building is a structure in which at least

50% of its height comes from floor plates
where people can live, work, chill out- it

has to be habitable. Any less than that and
it's not a building- it's a tower. After the

Lincoln Cathedral finally surpassed the height
of the pyramids, a number of churches continued

to be built that kept breaking and setting
new records. The next long-term record holder

was the Eiffel
Tower. It was the tallest thing, ever in history,

that we had built, for about 40 years in a
row. It was finally surpassed by the Chrysler

Building in New York, a personal favorite,
which was then quickly bested by the Empire

State Building. Now, the Empire State Building
is interesting in that it was the first structure

ever built by man that was so tall, were you
to jump off the top of it, you would actually

reach terminal velocity before you hit the
bottom. It was the first structure we'd ever

built that was so tall, rather than just continuing
to accelerate as you fell, you would actually

stop accelerating because you would reach
the fastest possible speed your limp body

could fall at. In the mid 1950's, something
weird started to happen: Humans started to

build radio and TV towers. These things could
be way taller than the buildings that we'd

made previously that had to be habitable.
And, so, ever since the Empire State Building

had its record broken by a TV tower, all these
other famously tall buildings, the Petronas

Towers, Tapei 101, the World Trade Center,
the Willis Tower (formerly Sears Tower)- none

have them have ever, within their existence,
actually held the title for being the tallest

"thing" we've ever built. There was always
a radio or TV tower somewhere that was taller.

Up until quite recently, and for quite a while,
the record for the tallest thing ever built

by humans went to the Warsaw radio mast in
Poland. It's visually incredibly striking

because there aren't any other sky scrapers
around it. It's all alone, being very tall.

Well, that was until 1991, where some workers
exchanging guy-wires made a mistake, and the

whole thing started to bend and then snapped
in the middle. There's no video of the event

happening, but it would have been similar
to this collapse, though much, much taller.

After the Warsaw radio mast collapsed, the
KVLY-TV mast in North Dakota became the tallest,

still standing, structure built by man. But,
recently, buildings have made a comeback.

And, to check that out, we're going to have
to travel to the Middle East. This is the

first time I've ever touched 
the
Nile. Tadaaa. Ok, so that was me dipping my

waterproofed
camera into the Nile. If you were to take

the entire length of the Nile River and stand
it up on it's edge, perpendicular to the Earth,

it would reach into outer space about this
far, which is pretty impressive. But, where

does the space shuttle orbit? And where does
the International Space Station orbit? This

far away? This far away?? Maybe, this far
away? Actually, if this pink, inflatable "Horrible

Bosses" ball was the Earth, the space shuttle
would orbit about right there. It's incredible,

but it's possible because the shuttle, and
the International Space Station, travels so

quickly. They travel so quickly around the
Earth that, instead of seeing one sunrise

and sunset every 24 hours, they see 16. But,
don't be jealous. You can easily see more

than one sunrise and/or sunset in a day by
taking advantage of tall structures. So, let's

take a look at the tallest structure, the
current record holder for the tallest thing

humans have ever built, the Burj Khalifa in
Dubai. The height of this building blows my

mind. You can literally watch the sunset from
the base of the building, and then take a

super-fast elevator all-the-way up to the
top and watch the same sun set again. In fact,

the difference
in timing between sunset at the base and the

top is so significant, the Dubai Islamic Affairs
department actually had to make a ruling about

when you can start, and break, your fast during
Ramadan inside the building. People above

floor 80 or higher have to actually wait to
start eating 2-3 minutes after the people

at the base, because the sun hasn't yet set
for those at the top. But, before you head

to Dubai to watch the sun rise, or set, twice
in a day, keep in mind that the only height

you actually need to see two sunrises or sunsets
is the height of your own body. Try this the

next time you're
at a beach. Watch the sun rise, or set, over

the water. Water is important because it won't
have the terrain or hill issues that land

does. Now, let's say you're watching a sunset-
begin by laying on your stomach. Watch the

sun set, and, as soon as the last little bit
of sun goes below the horizon, quickly pop

up into a standing position, and, voilá,
you'll see the sun's back- part of it's back-
and it will set another time.

If you take a stopwatch and record the time
between the first setting and the second setting

that you witness, and, measure the height
of your eyes when you're laying down and when

you're standing, you can use those numbers
to calculate the radius of the Earth.

XKCD took this a little bit further by proposing
the "Double Sunset Date." Take your date out

to the beach in a cherry picker, and, sure
enough, it was calculated, given the speed

of a cherry picker, all you have to is move
about 6 feet up, and you can watch a beautiful
sunset all over again.

To put things in perspective, the Burj Khalifa
is nowhere near as tall as Mount Everest.

But, the tallest structure that we could potentially
build wouldn't be as tall as Mount Everest-

it would be way, way taller. Like, into space
taller. Of course, the problem with building

things that are really tall is that they get
heavier and heavier, and have to support their
own weight. But only up to a point.

If a structure was so tall that it wound up
at the altitude of a geostationary orbit,

it would start to feel a new force, not just
a gravitational force downward, but, all of

the sudden, this new, centrifugal force up,
and outward.

And so, a building that tall could be stable
through tension. And, more than 35,000 KM

high. This kind if structure is known as a
"Space Elevator."

Unfortunately, there aren't any materials
known to science today that are strong enough

to make building something that large feasable.
With the exception, maybe, of Carbon Nanotubes,

or Boron-Nitrate Nanotubes. Of course, if
we went to a smaller celestial body, like

the Moon, we could build one today out of
stuff like Kevlar.

There are a lot of different things that we
have to be wary of when we build a space elevator.

For instance, how do we dodge space debris?
One solution is to attach the Earth side of

the cable to a boat in the ocean that can
maneuver around and move the elevator away
from dangerous obstacles.

Another interesting point is that the taller
the cable, the faster the far end of it will

be traveling. In fact, if the cable is more
than 50,000 KM long, its far end will be travelling

near escape velocity, and simply walking outside
could take you to the Moon. But, why build

a space elevator? Well, because it would be
awesome. But also for better reasons too.

For instance, right now, in order to send
a pound of material into orbit, it costs about

11,000 dollars. But with a space elevator,
we could send the same amount of material

into orbit for only about 100 bucks. That
difference is so significant that Philip Ragan

has said that the first country to deploy
a space elevator will have a 95% cost advantage,

and will possibly be able to control all space
related activities. Alright, so here you see,

in the mirror, Alex
playing guitar while she holds a camera in

her mouth and records us. Impressive. I'm
here with Kristen from Barely Political. She's

visiting London, and if you enjoyed this episode
of BOAT, check out other episodes- I've got

them all up there. And, as always, thanks
for watching. Oh, and check out Kristen's
channel right there. Bye! Bye.

comments.text:
His comment about a structure being habitable therefore being called a 
building is correct.  If a structure is not habitable, it is simply called 
a structure, a non-habitable structure is not always a tower.  This is the 
difference between some guy on the internet and those of us who have 
actually gone to college to study Architecture. Non-habitable structure = 
STRUCTURE!  Don't believe everything you hear or read on the web, most have 
no idea what they are actually talking about. Other than that, very 
interesting video, carry on.﻿

comments.text:
Space elevator, could You hear me laughing? Ok, not, but is this man sure 
this will be stable? It's not only a fact of mass but also of torsion. If 
You build up an object which is 21747 miles height then the rotational 
speed of this thing at bottom is 1700 km/h and at the top: 10800 km/h. That 
is the first problem, the next: in between the tower is  affected by storms 
and air fluctuations so the structure has to be more stable than those 
storm effects. If You build up a structure of this height then a little 
effect in about 10 km height may destroy the whole structure and then the 
structure itself will come down or - the outer portion perhaps - will go up 
in space. And then it was the highest thing. The next: Every thing has an 
maximum lenght as a structure p.Ex. if You build up a wire of a length l 
then there is a mass which works on one end. And if the mass of the wire 
exceeds the max. strenght force of the matzerial then the material will be 
broken by its own weight. And for steel this length is (with certain 
security level) at about 6 km. You can use materials like glass as fibre 
(160 km) or sill as fibre (50 km) but don't forget that every material will 
undergo changings by influence of temperature, vibrations and so on. And 
with the time the material will be less good so You'll have to change them. 
But how will You cange material in 21700 km height? Or - even worse (in 
11000 km height? A single failure and the whole structure comes down. And 
the next is: What will You do against fast space objects surrounding the 
earth? Think of my first question (torsion) Does a structure widthstands a 
torsion by a collison of an object with speed difference of p.Ex. 1000 km/h 
at the top (21700 miles)? I don't think it. So this question of space 
elevator is quite a nice thinking but not real.﻿

comments.author: Jake Riley

comments.text:
+Void619 Calm down, Jethro.  I wasn't implying you were stupid.  I thought 
you might be referring to something in this video because you commenting ON 
THE VIDEO.  How dare I make that assumption, right?  The fact is, there are 
A LOT of people who misunderstand this video and think that's what is being 
talked about - - I thought you were one of them.  Especially since you used 
the word, 'actually'.  It implies that you were wondering what would happen 
if they ACTUALLY did what you thought they were talking about.  Anyway...

You could not EVER attach something to both the Earth and the moon because 
the Earth rotates once every 24 hours while the moon takes 28 days to 
orbit.  It is not a technological restriction that makes it impossible, 
it just IS impossible.  The surface of the Earth is moving at about 1,000 
mph relative to the surface of the moon.  It could never be attached.
comments.author: Willoughby Krenzteinburg

Ofc the moon is also rotating and a connection wouldn't be "possible".

new discovered materials? Are you some super brain to know what could 
happen?

It's about theory crafting and having fun to talk about something abstract.

reasons".

comments.author: Doober Jaz

comments.text:
+Doober Jaz The terrorists you are talking about have a problem with people 
that interfere in their internal affairs.  Namely, the United States.  I 
very seriously doubt that the United States ALONE would be responsible for 
the construction of a space elevator (when that happens), and also worth 
noting is the fact that we are probably AT LEAST a hundred years away from 
realistically building something like this.  To apply today's threats to 
one hundred years into the future is in itself naive, and it doesn't even 
fit today's politics either.

Secondly, where's the fear?  If they severed it, it's not like it would 
come crashing down anyway.  It would just fly off into space (the vast 
majority of it would anyway).  So they would have succeeded in preventing 
governments (and well-financed private space programs) from sending 
payloads into orbit.  This would not have any effect whatsoever on the 
absolute vast majority of the population - - and it would probably cost the 
'terrorists' an unimaginable amount of money to pull off.  I don't think it 
makes much sense.  Bigger (as in physical size) is not better.  Higher body 
count is better.  Bigger economic impact is better (better from the 
terrorist's perspective anyway).  Destroying the space elevator will not 
result in either a high death toll nor would it have much effect on the 
economy.  You would lose the ability to put payloads into orbit cheaply for 
a decade or so.  The average Joe funding the economy via taxes, spending 
and other similar means will not be affected by the absence of the ability 
of his government to send a payload into orbit.

Think about it this way.  If NASA stopped sending astronauts into space, 
are you going to stop buying milk?  No.  It would have no effect on you - - 
and you, and others like you are what drive the economy.

I strongly disagree with your assertion that a space elevator would be a 
viable terrorist target simply because it's really tall.  It's again - - 
extremely naive.
comments.author: Willoughby Krenzteinburg

so terrorism works be a factor.

I know that terrorists don't attack because they can. They do it to spread 
a message, or to spread fear. And destroying something like a space 
elevator would do both easily. 
All of that said, it would be quite easy to counter terrorists with the 
correct defences.

naive.

comments.text:
I really think that even disregarding the astronomically huge construction 
costs of a "space elevator" (7;30), that it could never be able to "put 
objects into orbit at $100 per pound".   Remember, that it doesn't put an 
object into orbit until that object is transported to over 22,000 miles up 
that cable.   I can assure you that no person will ever take that ride for 
as little as $15,000, lol.﻿
comments.author: 37rainman

comments.text: +Willoughby Krenzteinburg Wow, scary, I AM BEING MUTED, "shudder, shudder"
comments.author: 37rainman

comments.text:
+37rainman I said the REDUCTION of costs from the way we do it today to a 
space elevator is from the fuel we WON'T use anymore to out things into 
orbit. The FUEL is what costs so much TODAY.

You have major comprehension deficiencies, and this is a pointless 
conversation. You're being muted.
comments.author: Willoughby Krenzteinburg

comments.text:
+Willoughby Krenzteinburg Hey, sir, YOU said in your first comment on this 
very thread that the FUEL costs are "$100/lb", implying that that figure is 
somehow relevant to something. Look at that post again.   I was commenting 
on your comments, not some comments on a wiki article. That is all.  
Obviously, in any business, the fuel costs are a tiny percentage of the 
amount that business charges for its service.  (Also, you talk about 
someones  opinion in their wiki article about a technology in its infancy, 
as if that opinion were somehow gospel.  It is not.  Currently these 
are science fiction dreams)
    You are still talking about whether or not an astronaut has to pay 
something to go to the ISS. That is meaningless to the discussion (no he 
doesn't pay anything, he gets a huge salary to go there.  I and we, pay for 
him and the equipment to go there!).  You say $100 for energy to climb to 
orbit.  After the thing is built, there will be staggering costs to operate 
it.   So you have $40 bil to build it, and huge costs to operate it, each 
of those items of which will be multiples times the fuel , but here you are 
talking about fuel as if it is some major part of the enterprise. Just the 
cost of the huge surface  ship, and the people operating that ship, and the 
fuel required for that ship will dwarf the costs of energy to operate the 
elevator. Also, have you ever noticed that a budget for a govt project, 
ALWAYS overruns by 100 to 200%.  But enough of that! On to other subjects!  
You seem to imply that to put an object into orbit, the only costs to get 
it there will be the space elevator.  You do realize, I hope, that if you 
avail yourself of a spacesuit, go on this ride, and desire to take a 
spacewalk, the only place you can take that spacewalk is at or near to 
22,200 miles up.   In other words, to put objects into orbit at any other 
altitude will require a spaceship, personnel, and fuel.  I.e.,  huge costs 
beyond the costs of raising the object to 22,200 miles.  (I am certain that 
you realize that to put an object into orbit 250 miles up, you cant just 
take your elevator up to 250 miles up and dump it out -- it also needs a 
lateral speed of 17,000mph. more costs).  And speaking of that 17,000 mph, 
there are at least 10,000 articles up there going that speed.  What happens 
when one of them hits that tether?  Mighty unlikely I realize, but unlikely 
things do happen every day.   I realize that many questions can be asked 
about any technology that has been, and will be, but I think it is safe to 
say that rather then this we are going to find advancements of spaceplanes, 
and drives,  as methods to go into space.  I also realize that 60 years 
ago, people couldn't even imagine the technology present today, so I must 
admit that the future will be amazing.
comments.author: 37rainman

comments.text:
+37rainman​​ Are you under the impression that this elevator will be for 
public use? 

The $100/lb is the COST to put a payload in orbit. I think you are 
thoroughly confused. It's not like any 150 lb shmuck can walk up and hand 
them 15,000 bucks and take a ride. And even if he could, I'm not talking 
about what he is CHARGED to ride the elevator. I (and those that came up 
with the $100 figure) are talking about what it COSTS. Do you understand 
the difference. When you are CHARGED $100 for a plane ticket, the COST of 
flying your ignorant ass is a lot less than that - otherwise, I doubt the 
airline would stay in business. You smell what I'm cooking?! I am talking 
about COST. Can you grasp this? I find it especially ironic that you are 
calling ME naive. As for the construction costs, I got the figure from this 
article :

http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_elevator_economics

Whether or not you accept it is entirely irrelevant to the validity and 
accuracy of these estimates. Someone MUCH more informed than you came up 
with these figures. Your nonsense is not even worth a second glance (though 
entertaining the first time around) We are done here.
comments.author: Willoughby Krenzteinburg

comments.text:
+Willoughby Krenzteinburg First, it is irrelevant that  some senator might 
go on a space elevator for "free".   There is a cost/person -- there is 
nothing for free on this world.  (That statement really was naïve).   You 
saying that the cost/ride to 22k miles is $100/lb, just because the energy 
might cost that,  is hilarious -- when did the cost of a plane ticket ever 
become just  the cost of the fuel?
   20 to 40 billion!!!  Do you even at all begin to understand what such a 
project would involve?   Finally, I might ask, what is that elevator going 
to actually be used for?  To haul tourists up and down?  I guess you could 
use it to haul parts for spaceships up to 22,200 miles, and assemble the 
ship there, etc, etc.
    It is a very exciting project, but I seriously doubt that it will cost 
only $100/lb to take that trip. Again, BNSF says that their trains can 
transport 1 ton of cargo, five hundred miles, using 1 gallon of diesel.  
Using your logic, that ton should cost you  $3 to ship 500 miles, or you 
should be able to ride that 500 miles for about 30 cents.  Sound silly?  
Yes it does.
    So I guess, if in your life you see this project happen, see if it 
costs 20 to 40 billion in todays dollars, for the whole project,  and see 
whether you can get that 22,200 mile ride for 17,000 dollars in todays 
dollars.   And see if they actually give you a ticket for the price of the 
energy used to raise the pod and cargo.
comments.author: 37rainman

comments.text:
+37rainman The cost reduction is the fact that it won't take tens of 
thousands of tons of fuel (which has a tangible cost) every time you want 
to put a payload into orbit. The tangible cost would be the electricity 
required to operate the elevator - - which by their calculations, would 
cost about $100 per pound. 

What you are talking about is like a "ticket" price, and that's utterly 
irrelevant to what they are actually talking about. And even so, official 
personnel would be riding the elevator, and at the moment, I'm pretty sure 
astronauts do not have to pay to go to the ISS.....

Reasonably detailed estimates have put the cost of construction of a space 
elevator at about $20-40 billion. This is a fraction of what the ISS cost 
(150 billion), so I don't think you really have any idea what you are 
talking about, or you are just guessing without even thinking about 
verifying how accurate your guesses are....

Centrifugal force doesn't exist (unless you are in the rotating frame of 
reference). It's not an actual force that's causing the outward push that 
an orbiting object can feel, it's just what feels like a force that's 
caused by the object's inertia.

Or so I was taught thus far.﻿

comments.author: Jeff Rosenbury

comments.text:
There are several mistakes in your video.
You don't mean perpendicular to the earth, you mean perpendicular to the 
ground.
You can not watch "multiple" sunrises and sunsets, by going up or down in a 
building, you are simply watching the same sunset, again. It's not a 
different day. It would be the same as watching a sunset, then driving west 
really fast.All you are doing is changing your viewing position, on the 
same day. 
And changing the fasting times for people at the top of the tower doesn't 
count, because if they started fasting when the sun rose at the top of the 
tower, then their fasting time would be approximately 6 minutes longer, 
than those at the bottom. The obverse concept would be if you lived in a 
well, your (viewed) sunrise and sunset would only be a few minutes apart, 
but that's not the actual sunrise and sunset times.
It does not "cost" $11,000 to send a pound of material into orbit, that is 
only what NASA charges to do it. You can get a pound of anything into orbit 
for thousands and thousands less than that.﻿
